Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: An Accessible Platform for Engaging Children with Motor Impairments in the Classroom Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project focuses on developing an accessible educational platform that combines mobile interfaces and adaptive educational tablet applications (Apps) to support the needs of children with special needs. Tablet devices are known to provide an interactive experience that has revolutionized learning for children. Unfortunately, while these tablet devices are intuitive to utilize and easy for many children, those with disabilities are largely overlooked due to difficulties in effecting pinch-and-swipe gestures. This project thus addresses a direct need in our society by providing an integrated educational experience, focused on math education that addresses the diverse needs of children, while providing a solution for variations found in their disabilities. The contributions of this project include 1) the design of accessible math Apps usable by K-12 children with and without disabilities and 2) the design of apps that adapt educational content and provide feedback to parents and teachers based on real-time analytics. Given that there are over 93 million children worldwide living with a disability and, in the United States, children with disabilities are entitled to a free appropriate public education, there is a large potential of making both a commercial, as well as a societal, impact in this space.

This SBIR Phase II project addresses an unmet need by developing an innovative solution to enable children with motor disabilities access to mobile devices and Apps that could engage them fully into the educational system. This solution capitalizes on the availability of pervasive technologies by combining an accessible tablet interface and educational Apps that adapt to each child?s abilities in order to provide an accessible mobile solution. Tablet devices are known to provide an interactive experience that has revolutionized learning for children. Unfortunately, while these tablet devices are intuitive to utilize and easy for many children, those with motor limitations tend to have difficulties due to the fine motor skills required for interaction. As such, to address the growing utilization of tablets in the classroom environment, the specific research objectives of this effort include the design of methods that enable the embedding of educational math content into accessible tablet apps for training and evaluating cognitive skills, the design of methods that enable adaptation of the educational content based on real-time analysis of interaction data and correlated performance of the child, and the hosting of interactive design sessions with teachers, parents, and children to evaluate the usability of the system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tablet devices are known to provide an interactive experience that has revolutionized learning for children. Unfortunately, while these tablet devices are intuitive to utilize and easy for many children, those with motor limitations, such as children living with cerebral palsy or recovering from traumatic brain injury, tend to have difficulties due to the fine motor skills required for interaction. As such, as tablet devices are increasingly being integrated into the classroom environment, there is a measurable demographic of children that are not being given equal access. Given that there are over 6.4 million children with disabilities in the U.S, there is a large demographic of children that are now being overlooked by the introduction of tablet devices into the mainstream classroom environment. It seems natural therefore to capitalize on the widespread appeal found with tablet devices and the wealth of educational Apps available to design a system that supports the educational goals of children with disabilities.

As such, the Phase I work for this SBIR resulted in an MVP (minimum-viable product) of the components necessary to validate the feasibility of an accessible educational platform and validating the usability and usefulness of the platform in addressing the needs of children with motor disabilities. The outcomes included a functional accessible interface prototype along with three accessible K-2nd grade math apps that could adapt based on real-time interaction with the child. The conclusions derived from introduction of the MVP versions to teachers, parents, and children validated the market and societal need for a full expansion of the accessible educational platform for children with disabilities.

In Phase II, we identified and developed a comprehensive set of STEM concept apps designed to engage and augment learning for children with special needs in the classroom environment. These ranged from accessible math games that cover fundamental math concepts to a coding app for young children with special needs to interactive STEM e-books that blend virtual and physical interaction to enhance STEM learning. Using the baseline developed from Tommy the Turtle – Learn to Code app, with Phase IIA TECP funding, we developed an accessible coding app called Code for Gold, that was more content-suitable for middle school students. This involved extending the command structure so that more extensive coding could be performed as well as provide coding curriculum and challenges that were more appropriate for this age group. In our final SBIR Phase IIB project, we focused on augmenting our coding app and embedding interaction and scaffolding algorithms with an open-source robotic platform to guide children through the learning of computing concepts while coupling the interaction with apps accessible to children with special needs that are closely aligned to CS standards. We also co-developed a usability study that was used by teachers to evaluate the effectiveness of our interface, including our STEMDash teacher portal, which allowed teachers to monitor the learning progress of their students. 

Not only have we received a number of awards and recognitions for these accessible STEM tools and learning games, we’ve also hosted a number of workshops that have provided training to special education teachers and administrators, as well as engaged children with special needs in STEM learning opportunities.
